reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s reliance on VNM-style cardinal expected-value representation and its use of numeric thresholds (0.5/0.9) and gamble comparisons to motivate “fussiness/easygoingness.” That formal apparatus is a substantial part of the argumentative structure (especially Section 3 and the extinction-vs-utopia comparisons), so centrality is moderate-to-high. However, the position explicitly acknowledges that not all moral views are representable this way and then intentionally restricts the technical analysis to complete/VNM-satisfying views; so the critique mostly shows a limitation of scope rather than a direct refutation of the thesis within the paper’s stated framework. It also doesn’t establish that dropping VNM assumptions makes eutopia ‘easy’—incompleteness or lexicality could make the target equally narrow or narrower—so the weakening effect is limited. Most claims in the critique are broadly correct (incompleteness/lexicality/independence failures would undermine the specific cardinalization-and-threshold moves), but it overstates by implying the key comparisons are likely mere artifacts rather than an explicitly chosen, defended modeling choice. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Critique relies on contentious cardinal utility assumption
